name: NPR
text: Robert Fuller, a 24-year-old black man, was found dead, hanging from a tree in Palmdale, Calif. Family and supporters are pushing back on the county sheriff's department's assessment of a likely suicide, saying Fuller's death appears to be a lynching. https://t.co/sxk3dtyXpt

name: NPR
text: The Arizona governor lifted the state's stay-at-home order a month ago. Now, the average number of daily coronavirus cases has nearly tripled from two weeks ago. https://t.co/SrZWtfPClT

name: NPR
text:
Activists have been covering a statue of Gen. Robert E. Lee in Richmond, Va., with graffiti and posing for photos.

"The standing in front of it, the dancing — it symbolizes a level of freedom that black people have never had before," said one man.
https://t.co/5BOFA3bsy1

name: NPR
text:
During quarantine, Sarah Cooper started posting videos of herself lip-syncing to clips of President Trump. 

Cooper wanted to take away the press and staffers to show what it would look like if a black woman spoke like Trump in a meeting. @hereandnow
https://t.co/Nuaponjp7o

name: NPR
text:
He lives in Washington state. She lives just across the border in Canada. They'd planned to get married in May.

Then, the border closed. Now, they visit each other at a park on the border.

But they say they have faith things will work out — eventually.
 https://t.co/dB6eV1PYBW

name: NPR
text: Many are concerned that the federal government's $4.6 billion plan to protect Miami from storm surge during tropical storms and hurricanes doesn't directly address a more frequently felt threat: rising sea levels.   https://t.co/bq5vxeT6Rv

name: NPR
text:
Former Ravens player Brendon Ayanbadejo is reserving praise for the NFL's decision to shift its stance on athletes protesting.

"[I] would've loved to have people listen sooner, before there was a lot more violence, before there was a lot more lives lost." https://t.co/RRucMI7A2m

name: NPR
text:
NPR talked to eight black photographers about documenting the protests against police brutality and systemic racism. 

They spoke of personal histories, of being moved by moments of deep humanity and of witnessing compassion for black protesters. https://t.co/3mEOpvstJB https://t.co/PlxnLYHk9P

name: NPR
text:
Students look forward all year to their big end-of-year productions. So teachers across the country got creative this year, creating memorable plays and performances that will live on — online.
https://t.co/xOEskM5Dxf

name: NPR
text:
Mail ballots take longer to process than in-person votes. Experts say problems arise when voters don't understand that — and then delays in election results can become fertile ground for conspiracy theories.
https://t.co/zDYaLad0I1

name: NPR
text:
Staffers at the Los Angeles Times say top editors have failed to fulfill promises of racial equity at the paper — including in hiring, pay and newsroom coverage.

Some have used terms like "internal uprising" to describe their frustration.
https://t.co/8J3GygCZoD

name: NPR
text:
More than a third of all COVID-19 deaths in the U.S. have been elderly residents and workers at long-term care facilities.

Now, Texas is sending out a strike force to assess problems at nursing homes and to test residents.
https://t.co/QPBEyrAeDP

name: NPR
text:
Maria Ressa, the former CNN journalist who co-founded the Philippines' Rappler news site, has been convicted of cyberlibel — a controversial charge that she has maintained is a politically motivated effort to silence independent journalism.
https://t.co/otgXIrTVBE

name: NPR
text:
NPR asked four essential frontline workers — a nurse, mail carrier, warehouse worker and grocery store cashier — to share their insights with the class of 2020.

Here's what they have to say.
https://t.co/ogG1RqPEhV

name: NPR
text: BREAKING: The Supreme Court has delivered a historic victory for LGBTQ people — ruling that the federal law that ba… https://t.co/CevIqX8wWg

name: NPR
text:
France is further easing restrictions imposed after the COVID-19 outbreak, starting with the full reopening of cafes and restaurants and the lifting of bans on travel from European countries.

It comes as new cases have fallen dramatically since mid-April.
https://t.co/t9EFAVowK3

name: NPR
text:
One wildlife biologist is raising questions about the accuracy of coronavirus tests — drawing from lessons learned from trying to track an invasive species in the U.S.
https://t.co/w7rOMz2MpB

name: NPR
text:
The Supreme Court has refused to reexamine the much-criticized, modern-day "qualified immunity" doctrine created by judges that has shielded police and other government officials from lawsuits over their conduct.
https://t.co/x6YGyN7Ip3

name: NPR
text: Thousands of people marched in Brooklyn yesterday in solidarity with Black transgender people. The march aimed to h… https://t.co/iRgQMZnJea

name: NPR
text:
Planned Parenthood Action Fund is endorsing Joe Biden. The group also says it's spending 50% more this election cycle than 4 years ago.

"This is literally a life and death election," says Alexis McGill Johnson, acting president of Planned Parenthood.
https://t.co/srgIN4sN1D

name: NPR
text:
U.S. stock indexes slid today as dozens of new coronavirus cases were discovered in Beijing, prompting renewed lockdown measures. Cases are still rising in several U.S. states that have reopened their economies.
https://t.co/mWtzYuwNWi

name: NPR
text:
Aimee Stephens was the first trans person whose civil rights case was heard by the Supreme Court, according to the ACLU.

She died last month at the age of 59, before she could hear the decision.

But today, the Supreme Court ruled in her favor.
https://t.co/Ago20Hfw8L

name: NPR
text:
After nearly three weeks of protests around the country, several police departments have said they're moving to make reforms.

But when it comes to sweeping national change, it's unclear how far Washington will go.
https://t.co/1kVhUkmpJN

name: NPR
text:
A NASCAR team debuted a "Blue Lives Matter" car over the weekend.

The move comes days after NASCAR banned the Confederate flag at events — and after driver Bubba Wallace unveiled a Black Lives Matter paint scheme last week.
https://t.co/sDQkZIduUG

name: NPR
text:
In Texas, 47% of the state's nearly 1,900 COVID-19 deaths have been tied to skilled nursing and assisted-living facilities.
https://t.co/vCMDuUQIZ8

name: NPR
text:
Consumption of drugs and alcohol has increased in the U.S. during the pandemic.

But, at the same time, a host of financial challenges now threaten the existence of most addiction treatment centers across the country.
https://t.co/Z5QngvC1sb
